page.title: 10CHESTNUT TREE STUD,SLINFOLD
page.content: {Shire horses}originated from the Great English Black Horse. Henry the eighth first recognised them as an individual breed in 1887. The owners keep{14 Sampson shires on their stud in Slinfold. The horses are mainly kept for{breeding}but are occasionally shown at charity festivals. They are exported to America or sold to the Youngs' Brewery when 3 years old. Shires mainly eat hay, bran and a little sugar beet as they produce their own heat and energy. Therefore they are less expensive to keep, eating only grass in Summer. In Winter they live inside and are turned out in May. The owners work full time with the help of a full time groom. The largest shire in England, Lady Ann, 19 h, is kept on the stud. Shires cost from{Â£2,000 to Â£10,000.
